Cost-Effective Federated Learning Design

3IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY, USA
4Department of Electrical Engineering and Institute for Network Science, Yale University, USA

Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a distributed learning paradigm that enables a large number of devices to collaboratively learn a model without sharing their raw data. Despite its practical efficiency and effectiveness, the iterative on-device learning process incurs a considerable cost in terms of learning time and energy consumption, which depends crucially on the number of selected clients and the number of local iterations in each training round. In this paper, we analyze how to design adaptive FL that optimally chooses these essential control variables to minimize the total cost while ensuring convergence. Theoretically, we analytically establish the relationship between the total cost and the control variables with the convergence upper bound. To efficiently solve the cost minimization problem, we develop a low-cost sampling-based algorithm to learn the convergence related unknown parameters. We derive important solution properties that effectively identify the design principles for different metric preferences. Practically, we evaluate our theoretical results both in a simulated environment and on a hardware prototype. Experimental evidence verifies our derived properties and demonstrates that our proposed solution achieves near-optimal performance for various datasets, different machine learning models, and heterogeneous system settings.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) has recently emerged as an attractive distributed learning paradigm, which enables many clients111Depending on the type of clients, FL can be categorized into cross-device FL and cross-silo FL (clients are companies or organizations, etc.) [1]. This paper focuses on the former and we use “device” and “client” interchangeably. to collaboratively train a model under the coordination of a central server, while keeping the training data decentralized and private[2, 3, 1, 4, 5, 6]. In FL settings, the training data are generally massively distributed over a large number of devices, and the communication between the server and clients are typically operated at lower rates compared to datacenter settings. These unique features necessitate FL algorithms that perform multiple local iterations in parallel on a fraction of randomly sampled clients and then aggregate the resulting model update via the central server periodically [2]. FL has demonstrated empirical success and theoretical convergence guarantees in various heterogeneous settings, e.g., unbalanced and non-i.i.d. data distribution [7, 8, 2, 9, 10, 11].

Because model training and information transmission for on-device FL can be both time and energy consuming, it is necessary and important to analyze the cost that is incurred for completing a given FL task. In general, the cost of FL includes multiple components such as learning time and energy consumption [12]. The importance of different cost components depends on the characteristics of FL systems and applications. For example, in a solar-based sensor network, energy consumption is the major concern for the sensors to participate in FL tasks, whereas in a multi-agent search-and-rescue task where the goal is to collaboratively learn an unknown map, achieving timely result would be the first priority. Therefore, a cost-effective FL design needs to jointly optimize various cost components (e.g., learning time and energy consumption) for different preferences.

A way of optimizing the cost is to adapt control variables in the FL process to achieve a properly defined objective. For example, some existing works have considered the adaptation of communication interval (i.e., the number of local iterations between two global aggregation rounds) for communication-efficient FL with convergence guarantees [13, 14]. However, a limitation in these works is that they only adapt a single control variable (i.e., communication interval) in the FL process and ignore other essential aspects, such as the number of participating clients in each round, which can have a significant impact on the energy consumption.

In this paper, we consider a multivariate control problem for cost-efficient FL with convergence guarantees. To minimize the expected cost, we develop an algorithm that adapts various control variables in the FL process to achieve our goal. Compared to the univariate setting in existing works, our problem is much more challenging due to the following reasons: 1) The choices of control variables are tightly coupled. 2) The relationship between the control variables and the learning convergence rate has only been captured by an upper bound with unknown coefficients in the literature. 3) Our cost objective includes multiple components (e.g., time and energy) which can have different importance depending on the system and application scenario, whereas existing works often consider a single optimization objective such as minimizing the communication overhead.

As illustrated in Fig. 1, we consider the number of participating clients (K𝐾{K}) and the number of local iterations (E𝐸{E}) in each FL round as our control variables. A similar methodology can be applied to analyze problems with other control variables as well. We analyze, for the first time, how to design adaptive FL that optimally chooses K𝐾K and E𝐸E to minimize the total cost while ensuring convergence. Our main contributions are as follows:

  • •

    Optimization Algorithm: We establish the analytical relationship between the total cost, control variables, and convergence upper bound for strongly convex objective functions, based on which an optimization problem for total cost minimization is formulated and analyzed. We propose a sampling-based algorithm to learn the unknown parameters in the convergence bound with marginal estimation overhead. We show that our optimization problem is biconvex with respect to K𝐾K and E𝐸E, and develop efficient ways to solve it based on closed-form expressions.

  • •

    Theoretical Properties: We theoretically obtain important properties that effectively identify the design principles for different optimization goals. Notably, the choice of K𝐾K leads to an interesting trade-off between learning time reduction and energy saving, with a large K𝐾K favoring the former while a small K𝐾K benefiting the later. Nevertheless, we show that a relatively low device participation rate does not severely slow down the learning. For the choice of E𝐸E, we show that neither a too small or too large E𝐸E is good for cost-effectiveness. The optimal value of E𝐸E also depends on the relationship between computation and communication costs.

  • •

    Simulation and Experimentation: We evaluate our theoretical results with real datasets, both in a simulated environment and on a hardware prototype with 202020 Raspberry Pi devices. Experimental results verify our design principles and derived properties of K𝐾K and E𝐸E. They also demonstrate that our proposed optimization algorithm provides near-optimal solution for both real and synthetic datasets with non-i.i.d. data distributions. Particularly, we highlight that our approach works well with both convex non-convex machine learning models empirically.

II Related Work

FL was first proposed in [2], which demonstrated FL’s effectiveness of collaboratively learning a model without collecting users’ data. Compared to distributed learning in data centers, FL needs to address several unique challenges, including non-i.i.d. and unbalanced data, limited communication bandwidth, and limited device availability (partial participation) [1, 5]. It was suggested that FL algorithms should operate synchronously due to its composability with other techniques such as secure aggregation protocols [15], differential privacy [16], and model compression [17]. Hence, we consider synchronous FL in this paper with all the aforementioned characteristics.

The de facto FL algorithm is federated averaging (FedAvg), which performs multiple local iterations in parallel on a subset of devices in each round. A system-level FL framework was presented in [8], which demonstrates the empirical success of FedAvg in mobile devices using TensorFlow [18]. Recently, a convergence bound of FedAvg was established in [11]. Other related distributed optimization algorithms are mostly for i.i.d. datasets [19, 20, 21] and full client participation [22, 9, 23], which do not capture the essence of on-device FL. Some extensions of FedAvg considered aspects such as adding a proximal term [10] and using accelerated gradient descent methods [24]. These works did not consider optimization for cost/resource efficiency.

Literature in FL cost optimization mainly focused on learning time and on-device energy consumption. The optimization of learning time was studied in [25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32], and joint optimization for learning time and energy consumption was considered in [33, 34, 35]. These works considered cost-aware client scheduling [25, 26, 27, 28], task offloading[36] and resource (e.g., transmission power, communication bandwidth, and CPU frequency) allocation [29, 30, 12, 33, 34, 35] for pre-specified (i.e., non-optimized) design parameters (K𝐾K and E𝐸E in our case) of the FL algorithm.

The optimization of a single design parameter E𝐸E or the amount of information exchange, in general, was studied in [13, 14, 12, 31, 37, 38], most of which assume full client participation and can be infeasible for large-scale on-device FL. A very recent work in [39] considered the optimization of both E𝐸E and client selection for additive per-client costs. However, the cost related to learning time in our problem is non-additive on a per-client basis, because different clients perform local model updates in parallel. In addition, the convergence bound used in [39] (and also [12]) is for a primal-dual optimization algorithm, which is different from the commonly used FedAvg algorithm and does not reflect the impact of key FL characteristics such as partial client participation. The challenge in optimizing both K𝐾K and E𝐸E for cost minimization of FedAvg that takes into account all the aforementioned FL characteristics, which also distinguishes our work from the above, is the need to analytically connect the total cost with multiple control variables as well as with the convergence rate.

In addition, most existing work on FL are based on simulations, whereas we implement our algorithm in an actual hardware prototype with resource-constrained devices.

Roadmap: We present the system model and problem formulation in Section III. In Section IV, we analyze the cost minimization problem and present an algorithm to solve it. We provide theoretical analysis on the solution properties in Section V. Experimentation results are given in Section VI and the conclusion is presented in Section VII.

III System Model

We start by summarizing the basics of FL and its de facto algorithm FedAvg. Then, we present the cost model for a given FL task, and introduce our optimization problem formulation.

III-A Federated Learning

Consider a scenario with a large population of mobile clients that have data for training a machine learning model. Due to data privacy and bandwidth limitation concerns, it is not desirable for clients to disclose and send their raw data to a high-performance data center. FL is a decentralized learning framework that aims to resolve this problem. Mathematically, FL is the following distributed optimization problem:

min𝐰⁡F​(𝐰):=∑k=1Npk​Fk​(𝐰)assignsubscript𝐰𝐹𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰\min_{\mathbf{w}}F\left(\mathbf{w}\right):=\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{N}{p_{k}}{F_{k}}\left(\mathbf{w}\right) (1)

where the objective F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F\left(\mathbf{w}\right) is also known as the global loss function, 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} is the model parameter vector, N𝑁N is the total number of devices, and pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} is the weight of the k𝑘k-th device such that ∑k=1Npk=1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑘1\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{N}p_{k}=1. Suppose the k𝑘k-th device has nksubscript𝑛𝑘n_{k} training data samples (𝐱k,1,⋯,𝐱k,nksubscript𝐱𝑘1⋯subscript𝐱𝑘subscript𝑛𝑘\mathbf{x}_{k,1},\cdots,\mathbf{x}_{k,n_{k}}), and the total number of training data samples across N𝑁N devices is n:=∑k=1Nnkassign𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑛𝑘n:=\sum\nolimits_{k\!=\!1}^{N}n_{k}, then we have pk=nknsubscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑛𝑘𝑛p_{k}=\frac{n_{k}}{n}. The local loss function of client k𝑘k is

Fk​(𝐰):=1nk​∑j=1nkf​(𝐰;𝐱k,j),assignsubscript𝐹𝑘𝐰1subscript𝑛𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑘𝑓𝐰subscript𝐱𝑘𝑗{F_{k}}\left(\mathbf{w}\right):=\frac{1}{{{n_{k}}}}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{n_{k}}{{f}\left(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{x}_{k,j}\right)}, (2)

where f​(⋅)𝑓⋅f(\cdot) represents a per-sample loss function, e.g., mean square error and cross entropy applied to the output of a model with parameter 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} and input data sample 𝐱k,jsubscript𝐱𝑘𝑗\mathbf{x}_{k,j} [13].

FedAvg (Algorithm 1) was proposed in [2] to solve (1). In each round r𝑟r, a subset of randomly selected clients 𝒦(r)superscript𝒦𝑟\mathcal{K}^{(r)} run E𝐸E steps222E𝐸E is originally defined as epochs of SGD in [2]. In this paper we denote E𝐸E as the number of local iteration for theoretically analysis. of stochastic gradient decent (SGD) on (2) in parallel, where 𝒦(r)⊆{1,2,…,N}superscript𝒦𝑟12…𝑁\mathcal{K}^{(r)}\subseteq\{1,2,...,N\}. Then, the updated model parameters of these |𝒦(r)|superscript𝒦𝑟\left|\mathcal{K}^{(r)}\right| clients are sent to and aggregated by the server. This process repeats for many rounds until the global loss converges. Let R𝑅R be the total number of rounds, then the total number of iterations for each device is E​R𝐸𝑅ER.

While FL has demonstrated its effectiveness in many application scenarios, practitioners also need to take into account the cost that is incurred for completing a given task.

III-B Cost Analysis of Federated Learning

The total cost of FL, according to Algorithm 1, involves learning time and energy consumption, both of which are consumed during local computation (Line 1) and global communication (Lines 1 and 1) in each round. Before presenting each cost model, we first give the system assumptions.

System assumptions: Similar to existing works [2, 11, 10], we sample K𝐾K clients in each round r𝑟r (i.e., K:=|𝒦(r)|assign𝐾superscript𝒦𝑟K:=\left|\mathcal{K}^{(r)}\right|) where the sampling is uniform (without replacement) out of all N𝑁N clients. We assume the communication and computation cost for a particular device in each round is the same, but varies among devices due to system heterogeneity. We do not consider the cost for model aggregation in Line 1, because it only needs to compute the average that is much less complex than local model updates.

III-B1 Time Cost

For general heterogeneous systems, each client can have different communication and computation capabilities (see Fig. 1). Let tksubscript𝑡𝑘t_{k} denote the per-round time for client k𝑘k to complete computation and communication. We have

tk=tk,p​E+tk,m​∀k∈{1,…,N},subscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘𝑝𝐸subscript𝑡𝑘𝑚for-all𝑘1…𝑁t_{k}=t_{k,p}E+t_{k,m}\ \forall k\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, (3)

where tk,psubscript𝑡𝑘𝑝t_{k,p} is the computation time for client k𝑘k to perform one local iteration, and tk,msubscript𝑡𝑘𝑚t_{k,m} is the per-round communication time for a client to upload/download the model parameter.

Because the clients compute and communicate in parallel, for each round r𝑟r, the per-round time t(r)superscript𝑡𝑟t^{(r)} depends on the slowest participating client (also known as straggler).333This is because in synchronized FL systems, the server needs to collect all updates from the sampled clients before performing global aggregation. Hence,

t(r)=maxk∈𝒦(r)⁡{tk}.superscript𝑡𝑟subscript𝑘superscript𝒦𝑟subscript𝑡𝑘t^{(r)}=\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}^{(r)}}\left\{t_{k}\right\}. (4)

Therefore, the total learning time ttotsubscript𝑡tott_{\textnormal{tot}} after R𝑅R rounds is

ttot​(K,E,R)=∑r=1Rmaxk∈𝒦(r)⁡{tk}.subscript𝑡tot𝐾𝐸𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑅subscript𝑘superscript𝒦𝑟subscript𝑡𝑘t_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)=\sum\nolimits_{r=1}^{R}\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}^{(r)}}\left\{t_{k}\right\}. (5)

III-B2 Energy Cost

Similarly, by denoting eksubscript𝑒𝑘e_{k} as the per-round energy cost for client k𝑘k to complete the computation and communication, we have

ek=ek,p​E+ek,m,subscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑒𝑘𝑝𝐸subscript𝑒𝑘𝑚e_{k}=e_{k,p}E+e_{k,m}, (6)

where ek,psubscript𝑒𝑘𝑝e_{k,p} and ek,msubscript𝑒𝑘𝑚e_{k,m} are respectively the energy costs for client k𝑘k to perform a local iteration and a round of communication.

Unlike the straggling effect in time cost (4), the energy cost e(r)superscript𝑒𝑟e^{(r)} in each round r𝑟r depends on the sum energy consumption of the selected clients 𝒦(r)superscript𝒦𝑟\mathcal{K}^{(r)}. Therefore, the total energy cost etotsubscript𝑒tote_{\textnormal{tot}} after R𝑅R rounds can be expressed as

etot​(K,E,R)=∑r=1R∑k∈𝒦(r)ek.subscript𝑒tot𝐾𝐸𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑅subscript𝑘superscript𝒦𝑟subscript𝑒𝑘e_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)=\sum\nolimits_{r=1}^{R}\sum\nolimits_{k\in\mathcal{K}^{(r)}}e_{k}. (7)

III-C Problem Formulation

Considering the difference of the two cost metrics, the optimal solutions of E𝐸E, K𝐾K and R𝑅R generally do not achieve the common goal for minimizing both ttotsubscript𝑡tott_{\textnormal{tot}} and etotsubscript𝑒tote_{\textnormal{tot}}. To strike the balance of learning time and energy consumption, we introduce a weight γ∈[0,1]𝛾01\gamma\in\left[0,1\right] and optimize the balanced cost function in the following form:

Ctot​(K,E,R)=(1−γ)​ttot​(K,E,R)+γ​etot​(K,E,R),subscript𝐶tot𝐾𝐸𝑅1𝛾subscript𝑡tot𝐾𝐸𝑅𝛾subscript𝑒tot𝐾𝐸𝑅C_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)=\left(1-\gamma\right)t_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)+\gamma e_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R), (8)

where 1−γ1𝛾1-\gamma and γ𝛾\gamma can be interpreted as the normalized price of the two costs, i.e., how much monetary cost for one unit of time and one unit of energy, respectively. The value of γ𝛾\gamma can be adjusted for different preferences. For example, we can set γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0 when all clients are plugged in and energy consumption is not a major concern, whereas γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1 when devices are solar-based sensors where saving the devices’ energy is the priority.

Our goal is to minimize the expected total cost while ensuring convergence, which translates into this problem:

P1:minE,K,R𝔼​[Ctot​(E,K,R)] s.t. 𝔼​[F​(𝐰R)]−F∗≤ϵ,K,E,R∈ℤ+,and​ 1≤K≤N.P1:subscript𝐸𝐾𝑅𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot𝐸𝐾𝑅 s.t. 𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝐰𝑅superscript𝐹italic-ϵmissing-subexpressionformulae-sequence𝐾𝐸𝑅superscriptℤand1𝐾𝑁\begin{array}[]{cl}\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\textbf{P1:}\quad\quad\min_{E,K,R}&\mathbb{E}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}(E,K,R)]\\ \quad\quad\text{ s.t. }&\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}_{R})]-F^{*}\leq\epsilon,\\ &K,E,R\in\mathbb{Z}^{+},\ \text{and}\ \ 1\leq K\leq N.\end{array} (9)

where 𝔼​[F​(𝐰R)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝐰𝑅\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}_{R})] is the expected loss after R𝑅R rounds, F∗superscript𝐹F^{*} is the (true and unknown) minimum value of F𝐹F, and ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is the desired precision. We note that the expectation in P1 is due to the randomness of SGD and client sampling in each round.

Solving P1 is challenging in two aspects. First, it is difficult to find an exact analytical expression to relate E𝐸E, K𝐾K and R𝑅R with Ctotsubscript𝐶totC_{\textnormal{tot}}, especially due to the non-linear maximum function in ttotsubscript𝑡tott_{\textnormal{tot}}. Second, it is generally impossible to obtain an exact analytical relationship to connect E𝐸E, K𝐾K and R𝑅R with the convergence constraint. In the following section, we propose an algorithm that approximately solves P1, which we later show with extensive experiments that the proposed solution can achieve a near-optimal performance of P1.

IV Cost-Effective Optimization Algorithm

This section shows how to approximately solve P1. We first formulate an alternative problem that includes an approximate analytical relationship between the expected cost 𝔼​[Ctot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\mathbb{E}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}], the convergence constraint, and the control variables E𝐸E, K𝐾K and R𝑅R. Then, we show that this new optimization problem can be efficiently solved after estimating unknown parameters associated with the convergence bound, and we propose a sampling-based algorithm to learn these unknown parameters.

IV-A Approximate Solution to P1

IV-A1 Analytical Expression of 𝔼​[etot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑒tot\mathbb{E}[e_{\textnormal{tot}}]

We first analytically establish the expected energy cost 𝔼​[etot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑒tot\mathbb{E}[e_{\textnormal{tot}}] with K𝐾K and E𝐸E.

Lemma 1.

The expectation of etotsubscript𝑒tote_{\textnormal{tot}} in (7) can be expressed as

𝔼​[etot​(K,E,R)]=K​(ep​E+em)​R,𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑒tot𝐾𝐸𝑅𝐾subscript𝑒𝑝𝐸subscript𝑒𝑚𝑅\mathbb{E}[e_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)]=K\left(e_{p}E+e_{m}\right)R, (10)

where ep:=∑k=1Nek,pNassignsubscript𝑒𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑒𝑘𝑝𝑁e_{p}:=\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{N}e_{k,p}}{N} and em:=∑k=1Nek,mNassignsubscript𝑒𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑒𝑘𝑚𝑁e_{m}:=\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{N}e_{k,m}}{N} denote the average per-device energy consumption for one local iteration and one round of communication, respectively.

Proof.

Since all devices are sampled uniformly at random in each round, for R𝑅R rounds, each device will be sampled in K​RN𝐾𝑅𝑁\frac{KR}{N} rounds in expectation. Given that each device k𝑘k consumes ek,p​E+ek,msubscript𝑒𝑘𝑝𝐸subscript𝑒𝑘𝑚e_{k,p}E+e_{k,m} energy in each round as shown in (6), summing up K​RN​(ek,p​E+ek,m)𝐾𝑅𝑁subscript𝑒𝑘𝑝𝐸subscript𝑒𝑘𝑚\frac{KR}{N}\left(e_{k,p}E+e_{k,m}\right) over all N𝑁N clients leads to (10). ∎

IV-A2 Analytical Expression of 𝔼​[ttot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑡tot\mathbb{E}[t_{\textnormal{tot}}]

Next, we show how to tackle the straggling effect to establish the expected time cost 𝔼​[ttot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑡tot\mathbb{E}[t_{\textnormal{tot}}] with the control variables. Without loss of generality, we reorder {tk:∀k∈{1,2,…,N}}conditional-setsubscript𝑡𝑘for-all𝑘12…𝑁\{t_{k}:\forall k\in\{1,2,...,N\}\}, such that

t1≤t2≤…≤tk≤…≤tN.subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2…subscript𝑡𝑘…subscript𝑡𝑁t_{1}\leq t_{2}\leq\ldots\leq t_{k}\leq\ldots\leq t_{N}. (11)
Lemma 2.

With the reordered tksubscript𝑡𝑘t_{k} as in (11), the expectation of ttotsubscript𝑡tott_{\textnormal{tot}} in (5) can be expressed as444The notation of CNKsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑁𝐾C_{N}^{K} is also noted as (NK)binomial𝑁𝐾{{N}\choose{K}} which represents the combination number of choosing K𝐾K out of N𝑁N without replacement.

𝔼​[ttot​(K,E,R)]=∑i=KNCi−1K−1​tiCNK​R.𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑡tot𝐾𝐸𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑖𝐾𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖1𝐾1subscript𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑁𝐾𝑅\begin{array}[]{c}\mathbb{E}[t_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)]=\frac{\sum\nolimits_{i=K}^{N}{C_{i-1}^{K-1}t_{i}}}{C_{N}^{K}}R.\end{array} (12)
Proof.

We omit the full proof due to page limitation. The idea is to show that the expectation of the per-round time in (4) is

𝔼​[t(r)]=1CNK​∑i=KNCi−1K−1​ti.𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑡𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑁𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑖𝐾𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖1𝐾1subscript𝑡𝑖\begin{array}[]{c}\mathbb{E}[t^{(r)}]=\frac{1}{C_{N}^{K}}\sum\nolimits_{i=K}^{N}{C_{i-1}^{K-1}t_{i}}.\end{array} (13)

We first use the recursive property of Cmn+Cmn−1=Cm+1nsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑚𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑚𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑚1𝑛C_{m}^{n}\!+C_{m}^{n-1}\!=\!C_{m+1}^{n} to show that the number of total combinations for choosing K𝐾K out of N𝑁N devices CNKsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑁𝐾{C_{N}^{K}} can be extended as CNK=∑i=KNCi−1K−1superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑁𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑖𝐾𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖1𝐾1{C_{N}^{K}}=\sum\nolimits_{i=K}^{N}{C_{i-1}^{K-1}}. Then, each combination (e.g., CN−1K−1superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑁1𝐾1C_{N-1}^{K-1}) corresponds to the number of a certain device (e.g., N𝑁N) being the slowest one (e.g., tNsubscript𝑡𝑁t_{N}). Since all devices are sampled uniformly at random, taking the expectation of all combinations gives (13). ∎

IV-A3 Analytical Relationship Between 𝔼​[Ctot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\mathbb{E}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] and Convergence

Based on 𝔼​[etot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑒tot\mathbb{E}[e_{\textnormal{tot}}] in (10) and 𝔼​[ttot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑡tot\mathbb{E}[{t_{\textnormal{tot}}}] in (12), the objective function 𝔼​[Ctot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\mathbb{E}[{C_{\textnormal{tot}}}] in P1 can be expressed as

𝔼​[Ctot]=((1−γ)​∑i=KNCi−1K−1​tiCNK+γ​K​(ep​E+em))​R.𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot1𝛾superscriptsubscript𝑖𝐾𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖1𝐾1subscript𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑁𝐾𝛾𝐾subscript𝑒𝑝𝐸subscript𝑒𝑚𝑅\begin{array}[]{c}\mathbb{E}[{C_{\textnormal{tot}}}]\!=\!\left(\frac{\left(1-\!\gamma\right)\sum\nolimits_{i=K}^{N}{C_{i-1}^{K-1}t_{i}}}{C_{N}^{K}}\!+\!\gamma K\left(e_{p}E+e_{m}\right)\right)R.\end{array} (14)

To connect 𝔼​[Ctot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\mathbb{E}[{C_{\textnormal{tot}}}] with the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-convergence constraint in (9), we utilize the convergence result [11]:

𝔼​[F​(𝐰R)]−F∗≤1E​R​(A0+B0​(1+N−KK​(N−1))​E2),𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝐰𝑅superscript𝐹1𝐸𝑅subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵01𝑁𝐾𝐾𝑁1superscript𝐸2\begin{array}[]{c}\mathbb{E}[F(\mathbf{w}_{R})]-F^{*}\leq\frac{1}{ER}\left(A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)E^{2}\right),\end{array} (15)

where A0subscript𝐴0A_{0} and B0subscript𝐵0B_{0} are loss function related constants characterizing the statistical heterogeneity of non-i.i.d. data. By letting the upper bound satisfy the convergence constraint,555We note that optimization using upper bound as an approximation has also been adopted in [13] and resource allocation based literature [12, 30, 35]. Although the convergence bound is valid for strongly convex problems, our experiments demonstrate that the proposed method also works well for non-convex learning problems empirically. and using (14) and Lemmas 1 and 2, we approximate P1 as

P2:​minE,K,R((1−γ)​∑i=KNCi−1K−1​tiCNK+γ​K​(ep​E+em))​R s.t. 1E​R​(A0+B0​(1+N−KK​(N−1))​E2)≤ϵK,E,R∈ℤ+,and​ 1≤K≤N.P2:subscript𝐸𝐾𝑅1𝛾superscriptsubscript𝑖𝐾𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖1𝐾1subscript𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑁𝐾𝛾𝐾subscript𝑒𝑝𝐸subscript𝑒𝑚𝑅 s.t. 1𝐸𝑅subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵01𝑁𝐾𝐾𝑁1superscript𝐸2italic-ϵmissing-subexpressionformulae-sequence𝐾𝐸𝑅superscriptℤand1𝐾𝑁\begin{array}[]{cl}\!\!\!\!\!\!\textbf{P2:}\ \min_{E,K,R}&\!\!\!\left(\frac{\left(1-\!\gamma\right)\sum\nolimits_{i=K}^{N}{C_{i-1}^{K-1}t_{i}}}{C_{N}^{K}}\!+\!\gamma K\left(e_{p}E+e_{m}\right)\right)R\\ \quad\text{ s.t. }&\!\!\!\frac{1}{ER}\left(A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)E^{2}\right)\leq\epsilon\\ &K,E,R\in\mathbb{Z}^{+},\ \text{and}\ \ 1\leq K\leq N.\end{array} (16)

Combining with (15), we can see that P2 is more constrained than P1, i.e., any feasible solution of P2 is also feasible for P1.

Problem P2, however, is still hard to optimize because it requires to compute various combinatorial numbers with respect to K𝐾K. Moreover, even for a fixed value of K𝐾K, the combinatorial term is based on the reordering of tksubscript𝑡𝑘t_{k} in (3), which is uncertain as the order of tksubscript𝑡𝑘t_{k} changes with E𝐸E. For analytical tractability, we further approximate P2 as follows.

IV-A4 Approximate Optimization Problem of P2

To address the complexity involved with computing the combinatorial term in (14), similar to how we derive (10), we define an approximation of 𝔼​[ttot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑡tot\mathbb{E}[t_{\textnormal{tot}}] as

𝔼~​[ttot​(E,R)]:=(tp​E+tm)​R,assign~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑡tot𝐸𝑅subscript𝑡𝑝𝐸subscript𝑡𝑚𝑅\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[t_{\textnormal{tot}}(E,R)]:=\left(t_{p}E+t_{m}\right)R, (17)

where tp:=∑k=1Ntk,pNassignsubscript𝑡𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑡𝑘𝑝𝑁t_{p}\!:=\!\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{N}t_{k,p}}{N} and tm:=∑k=1Ntk,mNassignsubscript𝑡𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑡𝑘𝑚𝑁t_{m}\!:=\!\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{N}t_{k,m}}{N} are the average per-device time cost for one local iteration and one round of communication, respectively. The approximation 𝔼~​[ttot]~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑡tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[t_{\textnormal{tot}}] is equivalent to 𝔼​[ttot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑡tot\mathbb{E}[t_{\textnormal{tot}}] in the following two cases.

𝔼​[ttot​(K,E,R)]=(tp​E+tm)​∑i=KNCi−1K−1CNK​R=(tp​E+tm)​R=𝔼~​[ttot​(E,R)].𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑡tot𝐾𝐸𝑅absentsubscript𝑡𝑝𝐸subscript𝑡𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖𝐾𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑖1𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑁𝐾𝑅missing-subexpressionabsentsubscript𝑡𝑝𝐸subscript𝑡𝑚𝑅missing-subexpressionabsent~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑡tot𝐸𝑅\begin{array}[]{cl}\mathbb{E}[{t_{\textnormal{tot}}}(K,E,R)]&=\left(t_{p}E+t_{m}\right)\frac{\sum\nolimits_{i=K}^{N}{C_{i-1}^{K-1}}}{C_{N}^{K}}R\\ &=\left(t_{p}E+t_{m}\right)R\\ &=\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[t_{\textnormal{tot}}(E,R)].\end{array}

𝔼​[ttot​(K=1,E,R)]=(t1+t2​…+tNN)​R=(∑k=1Ntk,p​E+∑k=1Ntk,mN)​R=(tp​E+tm)​R=𝔼~​[ttot​(E,R)].𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑡tot𝐾1𝐸𝑅absentsubscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2…subscript𝑡𝑁𝑁𝑅missing-subexpressionabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑡𝑘𝑝𝐸superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁subscript𝑡𝑘𝑚𝑁𝑅missing-subexpressionabsentsubscript𝑡𝑝𝐸subscript𝑡𝑚𝑅missing-subexpressionabsent~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑡tot𝐸𝑅\begin{array}[]{cl}\mathbb{E}[{t_{\textnormal{tot}}}(K=1,E,R)]&=\left(\frac{t_{1}+t_{2}\ldots+t_{N}}{N}\right)R\\ &=\left(\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{N}t_{k,p}E+\sum_{k=1}^{N}t_{k,m}}{N}\right)R\\ &=\left(t_{p}E+t_{m}\right)R\\ &=\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[t_{\textnormal{tot}}(E,R)].\end{array}

Based on the approximation 𝔼~​[ttot​(E,R)]~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑡tot𝐸𝑅\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[t_{\textnormal{tot}}(E,R)] in (17), we formulate an approximate objective function of P2 as

𝔼~​[Ctot​(K,E,R)]=(1−γ)​𝔼~​[ttot​(E,R)]+γ​𝔼​[etot​(K,E,R)].~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot𝐾𝐸𝑅1𝛾~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑡tot𝐸𝑅𝛾𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑒tot𝐾𝐸𝑅\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)]=\left(1-\gamma\right)\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[t_{\textnormal{tot}}(E,R)]+\gamma\mathbb{E}[e_{\textnormal{tot}}(K,E,R)]. (18)

Now, we relax K𝐾K, E𝐸E and R𝑅R as continuous variables for theoretical analysis, which are rounded back to integer variables later. For the relaxed problem, if any feasible solution E′,K′superscript𝐸′superscript𝐾′E^{\prime},K^{\prime}, and R′superscript𝑅′R^{\prime} satisfies the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-constraint in P2 with inequality, we can always decrease this R′superscript𝑅′R^{\prime} to some R′′<R′superscript𝑅′′superscript𝑅′R^{\prime\prime}<R^{\prime} which satisfies the constraint with equality but reduces the objective function value. Hence, for optimal R𝑅R, the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-constraint is always satisfied with equality, and we can obtain R𝑅R from this equality as

R=1ϵ​E​(A0+B0​(1+N−KK​(N−1))​E2).𝑅1italic-ϵ𝐸subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵01𝑁𝐾𝐾𝑁1superscript𝐸2\begin{array}[]{c}R=\frac{1}{\epsilon E}\left(A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)E^{2}\right).\end{array} (19)

By using 𝔼~​[Ctot]~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] to approximate 𝔼​[Ctot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\mathbb{E}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] and substituting (19) into its expression, we obtain

P3:minE,K((1−γ)​(tp​E+tm)+γ​K​(ep​E+em))⋅(A0+B0​(1+N−KK​(N−1))​E2)ϵ​Es.t.E≥1,and​ 1≤K≤N,P3:missing-subexpressionsubscript𝐸𝐾⋅1𝛾subscript𝑡𝑝𝐸subscript𝑡𝑚𝛾𝐾subscript𝑒𝑝𝐸subscript𝑒𝑚subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵01𝑁𝐾𝐾𝑁1superscript𝐸2italic-ϵ𝐸s.t.formulae-sequence𝐸1and1𝐾𝑁\begin{array}[]{cl}\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\textbf{P3:}\\ \min_{E,K}&\!\!\!\!\!\frac{\left(\left(1-\gamma\right)\left(t_{p}E+t_{m}\right)+\gamma K\left(e_{p}E+e_{m}\right)\right)\cdot\left(\!A_{0}+B_{0}\left(\!1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\!\right)E^{2}\right)}{\epsilon E}\\[6.0pt] \!\!\!\!\!\quad\text{s.t.}&\!\!\!{E}\geq 1,\ \text{and}\ \ 1\leq K\leq N,\end{array} (20)

where we note that the objective function of P3 is equal to 𝔼~​[Ctot]~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]. P3 is an approximation of P2 due to the use of 𝔼~​[Ctot]~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] to approximate the original objective 𝔼​[Ctot]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\mathbb{E}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}].

In the following, we solve P3 as an approximation of the original P1. Our empirical results in Section VI demonstrate that the solution obtained from solving P3 achieves near-optimal performance of the original problem P1. For ease of analysis, we incorporate ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in the constants A0subscript𝐴0A_{0} and B0subscript𝐵0B_{0} next.

IV-B Solving the Approximate Optimization Problem P3

In this subsection, we first characterize some properties of the optimization problem P3. Then, we propose a sampling-based algorithm to learn the problem-related unknown parameters A0subscript𝐴0A_{0} and B0subscript𝐵0B_{0}, based on which the solution K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} and E∗superscript𝐸E^{*} (of P3) can be efficiently computed. The overall algorithm for obtaining K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} and E∗superscript𝐸E^{*} is given in Algorithm 2.

IV-B1 Characterizing P3

The objective function of P3 is non-convex because the determinant of its Hessian ∂2𝔼~​[Ctot]∂2K​∂2𝔼~​[Ctot]∂2E−(∂2𝔼~​[Ctot]∂K​∂E)2superscript2~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶totsuperscript2𝐾superscript2~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶totsuperscript2𝐸superscriptsuperscript2~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot𝐾𝐸2\frac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial^{2}K}\frac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial^{2}E}-(\frac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K\partial E})^{2} is not always non-negative in the feasible set. However, the problem is biconvex [40].

Theorem 1.

Problem P3 is strictly biconvex.

Proof.

For any E≥1𝐸1E\geq 1, we have

∂2𝔼~​[Ctot]∂2K=2​(1−γ)​B0​N​(tp​E2+tm​E)(N−1)​K3>0.superscript2~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶totsuperscript2𝐾21𝛾subscript𝐵0𝑁subscript𝑡𝑝superscript𝐸2subscript𝑡𝑚𝐸𝑁1superscript𝐾30\frac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial^{2}K}=\frac{2(1-\gamma)B_{0}N\left(t_{p}E^{2}+t_{m}E\right)}{(N-1)K^{3}}>0.

Similarly, for any 1≤K≤N1𝐾𝑁1\leq K\leq N, we have

∂2𝔼~​[Ctot]∂2E=2​((1−γ)​tp+γ​K​ep)​B0​(1+N−KK​(N−1))+2​A0​[(1−γ)​tm+γ​K​em]E3>0superscript2~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶totsuperscript2𝐸absent21𝛾subscript𝑡𝑝𝛾𝐾subscript𝑒𝑝subscript𝐵01𝑁𝐾𝐾𝑁1missing-subexpression2subscript𝐴0delimited-[]1𝛾subscript𝑡𝑚𝛾𝐾subscript𝑒𝑚superscript𝐸30\begin{array}[]{cl}\dfrac{\partial^{2}\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial^{2}E}\!\!\!\!\!\!&=2\left(\left(1\!-\!\gamma\right)t_{p}+\gamma Ke_{p}\right)B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)\\ &\ \ +\dfrac{2A_{0}\left[(1\!-\!\gamma)t_{m}+\gamma Ke_{m}\right]}{E^{3}}>0\end{array}

Since the domain of K𝐾K and E𝐸E is convex as well, we conclude that P3 is strictly biconvex. ∎

The biconvex property allows many efficient algorithms, such as Alternate Convex Search (ACS) approach, to a achieve a guaranteed local optima[40]. Nevertheless, by analyzing the stationary point of ∂𝔼~​[Ctot]∂K=0~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot𝐾0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K}=0 and ∂𝔼~​[Ctot]∂E=0~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot𝐸0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial E}\!=\!0, we show that the optimal solution can be found more efficiently. This is because from ∂𝔼~​[Ctot]∂K=0~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot𝐾0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K}\!=\!0 we have K𝐾K in closed-form of E𝐸E as

K=(1−γ)​B0​N​(tp​E3+tm​E2)γ​[B0​(N−2)​E2+A0​(N−1)]​(ep​E+em).𝐾1𝛾subscript𝐵0𝑁subscript𝑡𝑝superscript𝐸3subscript𝑡𝑚superscript𝐸2𝛾delimited-[]subscript𝐵0𝑁2superscript𝐸2subscript𝐴0𝑁1subscript𝑒𝑝𝐸subscript𝑒𝑚missing-subexpression\begin{array}[]{cl}K=\sqrt{\frac{(1-\gamma)B_{0}N\left(t_{p}E^{3}+t_{m}E^{2}\right)}{\gamma\left[B_{0}(N-2)E^{2}+A_{0}(N-1)\right](e_{p}E+{e_{m}})}}.\end{array} (21)

By letting ∂𝔼~​[Ctot]∂E=0~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot𝐸0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial E}=0, we derive the cubic equation of E𝐸E as

2​(1−γ)​tp+γ​K​ep2​(1−γ)​tm+γ​K​em​E3+E2−A0B0​(1+N−KK​(N−1))=0,21𝛾subscript𝑡𝑝𝛾𝐾subscript𝑒𝑝21𝛾subscript𝑡𝑚𝛾𝐾subscript𝑒𝑚superscript𝐸3superscript𝐸2subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵01𝑁𝐾𝐾𝑁10missing-subexpression\begin{array}[]{cl}\frac{2\left(1-\gamma\right)t_{p}+\gamma Ke_{p}}{2\left(1-\gamma\right)t_{m}+\gamma Ke_{m}}E^{3}+E^{2}-{\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)}}\!=\!0,\end{array} (22)

which can be analytically solved in closed-form of K𝐾K via Cardano formula [41]. Therefore, for any fixed value of K𝐾K, due to biconvexity (Theorem 1), we have a unique real solution of E𝐸E from (22) in closed form. Then, with ACS method we iteratively calculate (21) and (22) which keeps decreasing the objective function until we achieve the converged K∗superscript𝐾∗K^{\ast} and E∗superscript𝐸∗E^{\ast}. This optimization process corresponds to Lines 2–2 of Algorithm 2, where Lines 2 and 2 ensure that the solution is taken within the feasibility region, and Line 2 rounds the continuous values of K𝐾K and E𝐸E to integer values.

IV-B2 Estimation of Parameters A0B0subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}}

Equations (21) and (22) include unknown parameters A0subscript𝐴0A_{0} and B0subscript𝐵0B_{0}, which can only be determined during the learning process.666We assume that tpsubscript𝑡𝑝t_{p}, tmsubscript𝑡𝑚t_{m}, tmsubscript𝑡𝑚t_{m} and emsubscript𝑒𝑚e_{m} can be measured offline. In fact, K𝐾K in (21) and E𝐸E in (22) only depend on the value of A0B0subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}}. In the following, we propose a sampling-based algorithm to estimate A0B0subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}}, and show that the overhead for estimation is marginal.

The basic idea is to sample different combinations of (K,E)𝐾𝐸\left(K,E\right) and use the upper bound in (15) to approximate F​(𝐰R)−F∗𝐹subscript𝐰𝑅superscript𝐹F(\mathbf{w}_{R})\!-\!F^{*}. Specifically, we empirically sample777Our sampling criteria is to cover diverse combinations of (K,E)𝐾𝐸\left(K,E\right). a pair (Ki,Ei)subscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝐸𝑖\left(K_{i},E_{i}\right) and run Algorithm 1 with an initial model 𝐰0=𝟎subscript𝐰00\mathbf{w}_{0}\!=\!\mathbf{0} until it reaches two pre-defined global losses Fa:=F​(𝐰Ri,a)assignsubscript𝐹𝑎𝐹subscript𝐰subscript𝑅𝑖𝑎F_{a}:=F(\mathbf{w}_{R_{i,a}}) and Fb:=F​(𝐰Ri,b)assignsubscript𝐹𝑏𝐹subscript𝐰subscript𝑅𝑖𝑏F_{b}:=F(\mathbf{w}_{R_{i,b}}) (Fb<Fasubscript𝐹𝑏subscript𝐹𝑎F_{b}<F_{a}), where Ri,asubscript𝑅𝑖𝑎R_{i,a} and Ri,bsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑏{R_{i,b}} are the executed round numbers for reaching losses Fasubscript𝐹𝑎F_{a} and Fbsubscript𝐹𝑏F_{b}. The pre-defined losses Fasubscript𝐹𝑎F_{a} and Fbsubscript𝐹𝑏F_{b} can be set to a relatively high value, to keep a small estimation overhead, but they cannot be too high either as it would cause low estimation accuracy. Then, we have

{Ri,a≈d+A0+B0​(1+N−KiKi​(N−1))​Ei2Ei​(Fa−F∗),Ri,b≈d+A0+B0​(1+N−KiKi​(N−1))​Ei2Ei​(Fb−F∗).casessubscript𝑅𝑖𝑎𝑑subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵01𝑁subscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝐾𝑖𝑁1superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖2subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐹𝑎superscript𝐹otherwisesubscript𝑅𝑖𝑏𝑑subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵01𝑁subscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝐾𝑖𝑁1superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖2subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐹𝑏superscript𝐹otherwise\begin{cases}R_{i,a}\approx d+\frac{A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K_{i}}{K_{i}(N-1)}\right)E_{i}^{2}}{E_{i}\left(F_{a}-F^{*}\right)},\\ {R_{i,b}}\approx d+\frac{A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K_{i}}{K_{i}(N-1)}\right)E_{i}^{2}}{E_{i}\left(F_{b}-F^{*}\right)}.\end{cases} (23)

from (15), where d𝑑d captures a constant error of using the upper bound to approximate F​(𝐰R)−F∗𝐹subscript𝐰𝑅superscript𝐹F(\mathbf{w}_{R})\!-\!F^{*}. Based on (23), we have

Ri,b−Ri,a≈ΔEi​(A0+B0​(1+N−KiKi​(N−1))​Ei2),subscript𝑅𝑖𝑏subscript𝑅𝑖𝑎Δsubscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵01𝑁subscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝐾𝑖𝑁1superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖2\begin{array}[]{c}{R_{i,b}}-R_{i,a}\approx\frac{\Delta}{E_{i}}\left({A_{0}\!+\!B_{0}\left(1\!+\!\frac{N-K_{i}}{K_{i}(N\!-\!1)}\right)\!E_{i}^{2}}\right),\end{array} (24)

where Δ:=1Fb−F∗−1Fa−F∗assignΔ1subscript𝐹𝑏superscript𝐹1subscript𝐹𝑎superscript𝐹\Delta:=\frac{1}{F_{b}\!-\!F^{*}}\!-\!\frac{1}{F_{a}\!-\!F^{*}}. Similarly, sampling another pair of (Kjsubscript𝐾𝑗K_{j}, Ejsubscript𝐸𝑗E_{j}) and performing the above process gives us another executed round numbers Rj,asubscript𝑅𝑗𝑎R_{j,a} and Rj,bsubscript𝑅𝑗𝑏R_{j,b}. Thus, we have

Ei​(Ri,b−Ri,a)Ej​(Rj,b−Rj,a)≈A0+B0​(1+N−KiKi​(N−1))​Ei2A0+B0​(1+N−KjKj​(N−1))​Ej2.subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝑅𝑖𝑏subscript𝑅𝑖𝑎subscript𝐸𝑗subscript𝑅𝑗𝑏subscript𝑅𝑗𝑎subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵01𝑁subscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝐾𝑖𝑁1superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑖2subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵01𝑁subscript𝐾𝑗subscript𝐾𝑗𝑁1superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑗2\begin{array}[]{c}\frac{E_{i}\left(R_{i,b}-R_{i,a}\right)}{E_{j}\left(R_{j,b}-R_{j,a}\right)}\approx\frac{{A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K_{i}}{K_{i}(N-1)}\right)E_{i}^{2}}}{{A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K_{j}}{K_{j}(N-1)}\right)E_{j}^{2}}}.\end{array} (25)

We can obtain A0B0subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}} from (25) (note that the variables except for A0B0subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}} are known). In practice, we may sample several different pairs of (Ki,Ei)subscript𝐾𝑖subscript𝐸𝑖\left(K_{i},E_{i}\right) to obtain an averaged estimation of A0B0subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}}. This estimation process is given in Lines 2–2 of Algorithm 2.

Estimation overhead: The main overhead for estimation comes from the additional iterations for the estimation of A0B0subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}}.

For M𝑀M sampling pairs, the total number of iterations used for estimation is ∑i=1MRi,b​Eisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑅𝑖𝑏subscript𝐸𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{M}R_{i,b}E_{i}, where Ri,bsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑏R_{i,b} is the number of rounds for sampling pair (Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i}, Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i}) to reach Fbsubscript𝐹𝑏F_{b}. If the target loss is FRsubscript𝐹𝑅F_{R} with the required number of rounds R𝑅R, then according to (15), the overhead ratio can be written as

∑i=1MRi,b​EiR​E∗≈∑i=1MRi,b​Ei​(FR−F∗)A0+B0​(1+N−K∗K∗​(N−1))⋅(E∗)2,superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑅𝑖𝑏subscript𝐸𝑖𝑅superscript𝐸superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀subscript𝑅𝑖𝑏subscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝐹𝑅superscript𝐹∗subscript𝐴0⋅subscript𝐵01𝑁superscript𝐾∗superscript𝐾∗𝑁1superscriptsuperscript𝐸∗2\begin{array}[]{c}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{M}R_{i,b}E_{i}}{RE^{*}}\approx\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{M}R_{i,b}E_{i}\left({F_{R}-F^{\ast}}\right)}{A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K^{\ast}}{K^{\ast}(N-1)}\right)\cdot({E^{\ast}})^{2}},\end{array} (26)

where K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} and E∗superscript𝐸E^{*} are obtained from Algorithm 2. For a high precision with FR−F∗→0→subscript𝐹𝑅superscript𝐹0F_{R}-F^{*}\rightarrow 0, the overhead ratio is marginal.

V Solution Property for Cost Minimization

We theoretically analyze the solution properties for different metric preferences, which not only provide insightful design principles but also give alternative ways of solving P3 to more efficiently. Our empirical results show that these properties derived for P3 are still valid for the original P1. In the following, we discuss the properties for γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0 and γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1, respectively. For ease of presentation, we consider continuous K𝐾K, K∗superscript𝐾K^{*}, E𝐸E, and E∗superscript𝐸E^{*} (i.e., before rounding) in this section.

V-A Properties for Minimizing 𝔼~​[Ctot]~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] when γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0

When the design goal is to minimize learning time (γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0), the objective of P3 can be rewritten as

minE,K⁡(tmE+tp)⋅(A0+B0​(1+N−KK​(N−1))​E2)⋅subscript𝐸𝐾subscript𝑡𝑚𝐸subscript𝑡𝑝subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵01𝑁𝐾𝐾𝑁1superscript𝐸2\begin{array}[]{c}\min_{E,K}\ \left(\frac{t_{m}}{E}+t_{p}\right)\cdot\left(A_{0}+B_{0}\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)E^{2}\right)\end{array} (27)

We present the following insightful results to characterize the properties of E∗superscript𝐸E^{*} and K∗superscript𝐾K^{*}.

Theorem 2.

When γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0, 𝔼~​[Ctot]~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] is a strictly decreasing function in K𝐾K for any given E𝐸E, hence K∗=Nsuperscript𝐾𝑁K^{*}=N.

Proof.

The proof is straightforward, as we are able to show for any E𝐸E, ∂𝔼~​[Ctot]∂K<0~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot𝐾0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K}<0. Since K≤N𝐾𝑁K\leq N, we have K∗=Nsuperscript𝐾𝑁K^{*}=N. The same result can also be obtained by letting γ→0→𝛾0\gamma\rightarrow 0 in (21). ∎

Remark: In practical FL applications, N𝑁N can be very large, and thus, full participation (K=N𝐾𝑁K\!=\!N) is usually intractable. However, since the objective function in (27) is strictly convex and decreasing with K𝐾K, as K𝐾K increases, the marginal learning time decrease becomes smaller as well. Therefore, when N𝑁N is very large, sampling a small portion of devices can achieve a relative good learning time. Our later real-data experiment shows that sampling K=20𝐾20K\!=\!20 out of N=100𝑁100N\!=\!100 devices achieves a similar performance as sampling all devices.

Based on the above finding, it is important to analyze the property of E𝐸E when K𝐾K is chosen sub-optimally. In line with this, we present the following two corollaries.

Corollary 1.

When γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0, for any fixed value of K𝐾K, as E𝐸E increases, 𝔼~​[Ctot]~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] first decreases and then increases.

Proof.

Taking the first order derivative of 𝔼~​[Ctot]~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] over E𝐸E,

∂𝔼~​[Ctot]∂E=B0​(2​tp​E+tm)​(1+N−KK​(N−1))−tm​A0E2.~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot𝐸subscript𝐵02subscript𝑡𝑝𝐸subscript𝑡𝑚1𝑁𝐾𝐾𝑁1subscript𝑡𝑚subscript𝐴0superscript𝐸2\begin{array}[]{c}\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial E}=B_{0}\left(2t_{p}E+t_{m}\right)\left(1+\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\right)-\frac{t_{m}A_{0}}{E^{2}}.\end{array} (28)

Since 0≤N−KK​(N−1)≤10𝑁𝐾𝐾𝑁110\leq\frac{N-K}{K(N-1)}\leq 1 for any feasible K𝐾K, (28) is negative when E𝐸E is small and positive when E𝐸E is large. ∎

Corollary 1 shows that for any given K𝐾K, E𝐸E should not be set too small nor too large for saving learning time.

Corollary 2.

When γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0, for any fixed value of K𝐾K, E∗superscript𝐸E^{*} increases as tmtpsubscript𝑡𝑚subscript𝑡𝑝\frac{t_{m}}{t_{p}} increases.

We omit the proof of Corollary 2 due to page limitation. Intuitively, Corollary 2 says that for any given K𝐾K, when tmsubscript𝑡𝑚t_{m} increases or tpsubscript𝑡𝑝t_{p} decreases, the optimal strategy to reduce learning time is to perform more steps of iterations (i.e., increase E𝐸E) before aggregation, which matches the empirical observations for communication efficiency in [2, 19, 20].

V-B Properties for Minimizing 𝔼~​[Ctot]~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] when γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1

When the design goal is to minimize energy consumption (γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1), the objective of P3 can be rewritten as

minE,K⁡(em​KE+ep​K)​(A0+B0​(1+N−KK​(N−1))​E2).subscript𝐸𝐾subscript𝑒𝑚𝐾𝐸subscript𝑒𝑝𝐾subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵01𝑁𝐾𝐾𝑁1superscript𝐸2\begin{array}[]{c}\min_{E,K}\left(\frac{e_{m}K}{E}\!+\!e_{p}K\right)\left(A_{0}\!+\!B_{0}\left(1\!+\frac{N-K}{K(N\!-\!1)}\right)\!E^{2}\right).\end{array} (29)

Besides the different metrics of emsubscript𝑒𝑚e_{m} and epsubscript𝑒𝑝e_{p}, the key difference between (27) and (29) is the multiplication of K𝐾K. Therefore, the main difference between γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1 and γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0 is in the properties related to K𝐾K, whereas the properties related to E𝐸E remain similar, which we show in the following.

Theorem 3.

When γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1, 𝔼~​[Ctot]~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] is a strictly increasing function in K𝐾K for any given E𝐸E, hence K∗=1superscript𝐾1K^{*}=1.

Proof.

It is easy to show that ∂𝔼~​[Ctot]∂K>0~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot𝐾0\frac{\partial\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}]}{\partial K}>0 for any given E𝐸E. Since K≥1𝐾1K\geq 1, we have K∗=1superscript𝐾1K^{*}=1. This conclusion can also be obtained when we let γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1 in (21) since 1≤K≤N1𝐾𝑁1\leq K\leq N. ∎

Remark: Theorem 3 shows that sampling fewer devices can reduce the total energy consumption, whereas according to Theorem 2, this results in a longer learning time. While this may seem contradictory at the first glance, we note that this result is correct because the total energy is the sum energy consumption of all selected clients. Although it takes longer time to reach the desired precision ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon with a smaller K𝐾K, there are also less number of clients participating in each round, so the total energy consumption can be smaller.

Corollary 3.

When γ=1𝛾1\gamma\!=\!1, for any fixed value of K𝐾K, as E𝐸E increases, 𝔼~​[Ctot]~𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶tot\tilde{\mathbb{E}}[C_{\textnormal{tot}}] first decreases and then increases.

Corollary 4.

When γ=1𝛾1\gamma\!=\!1, for any fixed value of K𝐾K, E∗superscript𝐸E^{*} increases as emepsubscript𝑒𝑚subscript𝑒𝑝\frac{e_{m}}{e_{p}} increases.

The proofs and intuitions for Corollaries 3 and 4 are similar to Corollaries 1 and 2, which we omit due to page limitation.

V-C Trade-off Between Learning Time and Energy Consumption

In the above analysis, we derived a trade-off design principle for K𝐾K, with a larger K𝐾K favoring learning time reduction, while a smaller K𝐾K favoring energy saving. For a given γ𝛾\gamma, the optimal K𝐾K achieves the right balance between reducing learning time and energy consumption.

Theorem 4.

Assume that the power used for computation and communication are the same (i.e., emtm=eptpsubscript𝑒𝑚subscript𝑡𝑚subscript𝑒𝑝subscript𝑡𝑝\frac{e_{m}}{t_{m}}=\frac{e_{p}}{t_{p}}), then K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} and E∗superscript𝐸E^{*} both decrease as γ𝛾\gamma increases.

We omit the full proof due to page limitation. Intuitively, emtm=eptpsubscript𝑒𝑚subscript𝑡𝑚subscript𝑒𝑝subscript𝑡𝑝\frac{e_{m}}{t_{m}}=\frac{e_{p}}{t_{p}} yields tptm=epemsubscript𝑡𝑝subscript𝑡𝑚subscript𝑒𝑝subscript𝑒𝑚\frac{t_{p}}{t_{m}}=\frac{e_{p}}{e_{m}}. Hence, the quantities tp​E+tmep​E+emsubscript𝑡𝑝𝐸subscript𝑡𝑚subscript𝑒𝑝𝐸subscript𝑒𝑚\frac{t_{p}E+t_{m}}{e_{p}E+e_{m}} and 2​(1−γ)​tp+γ​K​ep2​(1−γ)​tm+γ​K​em21𝛾subscript𝑡𝑝𝛾𝐾subscript𝑒𝑝21𝛾subscript𝑡𝑚𝛾𝐾subscript𝑒𝑚\frac{2\left(1-\gamma\right)t_{p}+\gamma Ke_{p}}{2\left(1-\gamma\right)t_{m}+\gamma Ke_{m}} in (21) and (22), respectively, remain unchanged regardless of the values of K𝐾K, E𝐸E, and γ𝛾\gamma. By some algebraic manipulations, we can see from (21) and (22) that when γ𝛾\gamma increases or E𝐸E decreases, the value of K𝐾K according to (21) decreases; when K𝐾K decreases, the solution of E𝐸E from (22) also decreases (note that this solution remains unchanged regardless of γ𝛾\gamma). Therefore, whenever γ𝛾\gamma increases, K𝐾K will decrease, then E𝐸E will decrease, and so on, until converging to a new (K∗,E∗)superscript𝐾superscript𝐸(K^{*},E^{*}) that is smaller than before, and vice versa.

VI Experimental Evaluation

In this section, we evaluate the performance of our proposed cost-effective FL algorithm and verify our derived solution properties. We start by presenting the evaluation setup, and then show the experimental results.

VI-A Experimental Setup

VI-A1 Platforms

We conducted experiments both on a networked hardware prototype system and in a simulated environment. Our prototype system, as illustrated in Fig. 2, consists of N=20𝑁20N=20 Raspberry Pis (version 4) serving as devices and a laptop computer serving as the central server. All devices are interconnected via an enterprise Wi-Fi router, and we developed a TCP-based socket interface for the peer-to-peer connection. In the simulation system, we simulated N=100𝑁100N=100 virtual devices and a virtual central server.

VI-A2 Datasets and Models

We evaluate our results both on a real dataset and a synthetic dataset. For the real dataset, we adopted the widely used MNIST dataset [42], which contains square 28×28=784282878428\times 28=784 pixel gray-scale images of 70,0007000070,000 handwritten digits (60,0006000060,000 for training and 10,0001000010,000 for testing). For the synthetic dataset, we follow a similar setup to that in [10], which generates 606060-dimensional random vectors as input data. The synthetic data is denoted by S​y​n​t​h​e​t​i​c​(α,β)𝑆𝑦𝑛𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑡𝑖𝑐𝛼𝛽Synthetic\ (\alpha,\beta) with α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta representing the statistical heterogeneity (i.e., how non-i.i.d. the data are). We adopt both the convex multinomial logistic regression model [11] and the non-convex deep convolutional neural network (CNN) model with LeNet-5 architecture [42].

VI-A3 Implementation

Based on the above, we consider the following three experimental setups.

Setup 1: We conduct the first experiment on the prototype system using logistic regression and MNIST dataset, where we divide 6,00060006,000 data samples (randomly sampled one-tenth of the total samples) among N=20𝑁20N\!=\!20 Raspberry Pis in a non-i.i.d. fashion with each device containing a balanced number of 300300300 samples of only 222 digits labels.

Setup 2: We conduct the second experiment in the simulated system using CNN and MNIST dataset, where we divide all 60,0006000060,000 data samples among N=100𝑁100N\!=\!100 devices in the same non-i.i.d fashion as in Setup 1, but the amount of data in each device follows the inherent unbalanced digit label distribution of MNIST, where the number of samples in each device has a mean of 600600600 and standard deviation of 20.120.120.1.

Setup 3: We conduct the third experiment in the simulated system using logistic regression and S​y​n​t​h​e​t​i​c​(1,1)𝑆𝑦𝑛𝑡ℎ𝑒𝑡𝑖𝑐11Synthetic\ (1,1) dataset for statistical heterogeneity, where we generate 24,5172451724,517 data samples and distribute them among N=100𝑁100N\!=\!100 devices in an unbalanced power law distribution, where the number of samples in each device has a mean of 245245245 and standard deviation of 362362362.

VI-A4 Training Parameters

For all experiments, we initialize our model with 𝐰0=𝟎subscript𝐰00\mathbf{w}_{0}=\mathbf{0} and SGD batch size b=64𝑏64b=64. In each round, we uniformly sample K𝐾K devices at random, which run E𝐸E steps of SGD in parallel. For the prototype system, we use an initial learning rate η0=0.01subscript𝜂00.01\eta_{0}=0.01 with a fixed decay rate of 0.9960.9960.996. For the simulation system, we use decay rate η01+rsubscript𝜂01𝑟\frac{{\eta}_{0}}{1+r}, where η0=0.1subscript𝜂00.1\eta_{0}=0.1 and r𝑟r is communication round index. We evaluate the aggregated model in each round on the global loss function. Each result is averaged over 50 experiments.

VI-A5 Heterogeneous System Parameters

The prototype system allows us to capture real system heterogeneity in terms of communication and computation time, which we measured the average tp=3.1×10−3subscript𝑡𝑝3.1superscript103t_{p}\!=\!3.1\times 10^{-3}s with standard deviation 2.3×10−42.3superscript1042.3\times 10^{-4}s and tm=0.34subscript𝑡𝑚0.34t_{m}\!=\!0.34s with standard deviation 1.56×10−31.56superscript1031.56\times 10^{-3}s. We do not capture the energy cost in the prototype system because it is difficult to measure. For the simulation system, we generate the learning time and energy consumption for each client k𝑘k using a normal distribution with mean tp=0.1subscript𝑡𝑝0.1t_{p}\!=\!0.1s, tm=2subscript𝑡𝑚2t_{m}\!=\!2s, ep=10−3subscript𝑒𝑝superscript103e_{p}\!=\!10^{-3}J, and em=2×10−2subscript𝑒𝑚2superscript102e_{m}\!=\!2\times 10^{-2}J and standard deviation of the mean divided by 333. According to the definition of γ𝛾\gamma, we unify the time and energy costs such that one second is equivalent to 1−γ1𝛾1-\gamma dollars ($) and one Joule is equivalent to γ𝛾\gamma dollars ($).

VI-B Performance Results

We first validate the optimality of our proposed solution with estimated value of A0B0subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}}. Then, we show the impact of the trade-off factor γ𝛾\gamma, followed by the verification of our derived theoretical properties.

VI-B1 Estimation of A0B0subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}}

We summarize the estimation process and results of A0B0subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}} for all three experiment setups in Table I. Specifically, using Algorithm 2, we empirically888Due to the different learning rates, the sampling range of E𝐸E in Setup 1 is larger than those in Setup 2 and Setup 3. set two relatively high target losses Fasubscript𝐹𝑎F_{a} and Fbsubscript𝐹𝑏F_{b} with a few sampling pairs of (K,E)𝐾𝐸\left(K,E\right). Then, we record the corresponding number of rounds for reaching Fasubscript𝐹𝑎F_{a} and Fbsubscript𝐹𝑏F_{b}, based on which we calculate the averaged estimation value of A0B0subscript𝐴0subscript𝐵0\frac{A_{0}}{B_{0}} using (25). The proposed solution K∗superscript𝐾K^{*} and E∗superscript𝐸E^{*} is then obtained from Algorithm 2. For comparison, we denote KOPTsubscript𝐾OPTK_{\textnormal{OPT}} and EOPTsubscript𝐸OPTE_{\textnormal{OPT}} as the empirical optimal solution achieved by exhaustive search on (K,E)𝐾𝐸\left(K,E\right).

VI-B2 Convergence and Optimality

Figs. 3 and 4 show the learning time cost for reaching the target loss under different (K,E)𝐾𝐸\left(K,E\right) for Setups 1 and 2, respectively.999For ease of presentation, we only show the convergence performance with ttotsubscript𝑡tott_{\textnormal{tot}} for γ=0𝛾0\gamma\!=\!0. In both setups, our proposed solutions achieve near-optimal performance compared to the empirical optimal solution, with optimality error of 2.61%percent2.612.61\% and 8.49%percent8.498.49\%, respectively. We highlight that our approach works well with the non-convex CNN model in Setup 2. Although the error rate in Setup 2 is higher than that in Setup 1, note that non-optimal values of (K,E)𝐾𝐸(K,E) without optimization may increase the learning time by several folds.

Fig. 5 depicts the performance of Ctotsubscript𝐶totC_{\textnormal{tot}} for achieving the target loss with γ𝛾\gamma under different (K,E)𝐾𝐸\left(K,E\right) in Setup 3, where our proposed solutions achieve near-optimal performance for all values of γ𝛾\gamma. Particularly, Fig. 5(d) shows that, throughout the range of γ𝛾\gamma, our approach has the maximum optimality error of 10.23%percent10.2310.23\% and an average error of 4.85%percent4.854.85\%.

VI-B3 Impact of Weight γ𝛾\gamma

Figs. 5(a) – 5(c) show that when the weight γ𝛾\gamma increases from 00 to 111 (corresponding to the design preference varying from reducing learning time to saving energy consumption), both the optimal and our proposed solutions of K𝐾K decrease from N=100𝑁100N\!=\!100 to 111. At the same time, both the optimal and our proposed solutions of E𝐸E, although with a small difference, decrease slightly as γ𝛾\gamma increases. We give the explanations of these observations in Section VI-B4 below. By iterating through the entire range of γ𝛾\gamma, Fig. 5(e) depicts the trade-off curve between the learning time cost and energy consumption cost, where our algorithm is capable of balancing the two metrics as well as approaching the optimal.

VI-B4 Property Validation

We highlight that our derived theoretical properties of K𝐾K and E𝐸E in Section V can be validated empirically, which we summarize as follows.101010The property of Corollaries 2 and 4 can also be validated, which we do not show in this paper due to page limitation.

  • •

    Figs. 3(c), 4(c), and 5(a) demonstrate that for any fixed value E𝐸E, the learning time cost (γ=0𝛾0\gamma\!=\!0) strictly decreases in K𝐾K, which confirms the claim in Theorem 2 that sampling more clients can speed up learning. Moreover, we observe in these figures that sampling fewer clients (15 out of 20 for Setup 1 and 20 out of 100 for Setups 2 and 3) does not affect the learning time much, which confirms our Remark. Nevertheless, Fig. 5(c) shows that for any fixed value E𝐸E, the energy consumption cost (γ=1𝛾1\gamma\!=\!1) strictly increases in K𝐾K, which confirms Theorem 3 that sampling fewer clients reduces energy consumption.

  • •

    Figs. 3(c), 4(c), 5(a)–5(c) demonstrate that, for any fixed value of K𝐾K, the corresponding cost first decreases and then increases as E𝐸E increases, which confirms Corollaries 1 and 3 as well as the biconvex property in Theorem 1. Since emtm=eptp=10−2subscript𝑒𝑚subscript𝑡𝑚subscript𝑒𝑝subscript𝑡𝑝superscript102\frac{e_{m}}{t_{m}}=\frac{e_{p}}{t_{p}}=10^{-2} in our simulation system, we observe from Figs. 3(c), 4(c), and 5(a) that both K∗superscript𝐾∗K^{\ast} and E∗superscript𝐸∗E^{\ast} decrease as γ𝛾\gamma increases, which confirms Theorem 4.

VII Conclusion

In this work, we have studied the cost-effective design for FL. We analyzed how to optimally choose the number of participating clients (K𝐾K) and the number of local iterations (E𝐸E), which are two essential control variables in FL, to minimize the total cost while ensuring convergence. We proposed a sampling-based control algorithm which efficiently solves the optimization problem with marginal overhead. We also derived insightful solution properties which helps identify the design principles for different optimization goals, e.g., reducing learning time or saving energy. Extensive experimentation results validated our theoretical analysis and demonstrated the effectiveness and efficiency of our control algorithm. Our optimization design is orthogonal to most works on resource allocation for FL systems, and can be used together with those techniques to further reduce the cost.
